What percent of the air is nitrogen gas? 78% 70% 82% 20% The majority of air you breathe in on the planet's surface is what gas? Nitrogen Oxygen Carbon Monoxide Carbon Dioxide cloze What percent of the air is nitrogen gas? (?=.*78%).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is 78%. cloze The majority of air you breathe in on the planet's surface is what gas? (?=.*Nitrogen).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is Nitrogen. What makes nitrogen gas so hard for nature to use? A strong chemical bond connects the atoms The gas is too high up in the atmosphere Nature has no use for an inert element like nitrogen The chemical bond between atoms is too volatile Where would you expect to find the most nitrogen that hadn't been chemically changed? The atmosphere The ocean Soil Farmlands cloze What makes nitrogen gas so hard for nature to use? (?=.*connects).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is a strong chemical bond connects the atoms. cloze Where would you expect to find the most nitrogen that hadn't been chemically changed? (?=.*atmosphere).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is the atmosphere. What happens during nitrogen transformation? Nitrogen chemically changes Nitrogen escapes into space The bond between nitrogen atoms strengthens Nitrogen is changed and incorporated into an organism Which of the following is not an example of nitrogen transformation? Nitrate in soil that washes into the river and mixes with water Nitrogen fertilizer that is used by a plant Bacteria decomposing a dead plant into ammonia Fungi decomposing a dead log into ammonium cloze What happens during nitrogen transformation? (?=.*chemically).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is nitrogen chemically changes. cloze Where would you expect to find the most nitrogen that hadn't been chemically changed? (?=.*river).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is Nitrate in soil that washes into the river and mixes with water. How do nitrogen-fixers change nitrogen to form a new, usable compound? They combine nitrogen with another element They force apart the bond between nitrogen atoms They give nitrogen a positive charge They fix nitrogen to clay particles in the soil Where would you least expect nitrogen-fixing bacteria to thrive? In a sealed jar with 100% nitrogen in the air and soil from outside In a sealed jar with 50% nitrogen and 50% oxygen in the air and soil from outside In a sealed jar with the same air and soil from outside and refrigerated each night In a sealed jar with 30% nitrogen, 30% oxygen, and 40% water vapor and soil from outside cloze How do nitrogen-fixers change nitrogen to form a new, usable compound? (?=.*combine).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is they combine nitrogen with another element. cloze Where would you least expect nitrogen-fixing bacteria to thrive? (?=.*100%).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is in a sealed jar with 100% nitrogen in the air and soil from outside In nitrogen fixation bacteria can convert nitrogen gas to what? Ammonium Nitrous Oxide Oxygen Nitric acid Where in the soil should nitrogen-fixing bacteria be the most common? The topsoil, 0-6 inches deep The subsoil, 6-12 inches deep The substratum, 1-2 feet deep Deeper than the substratum, 2+ feet deep cloze In nitrogen fixation bacteria can convert nitrogen gas to what? (?=.*ammonium).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is ammonium. cloze Where in the soil should nitrogen-fixing bacteria be the most common? (?=.*topsoil) .*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is the topsoil, 0-6 inches deep. What natural event can fixate nitrogen? Lightning A tornado A blizzard Rain What type of natural event can fixate nitrogen? A high energy event that breaks the chemical bond of nitrogen A high energy event that preserves the chemical bond of nitrogen An event so cold it freezes nitrogen out of the air Natural events can't fixate nitrogen cloze What natural event can fixate nitrogen? (?=.*lightning) .*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is lightning. cloze What type of natural event can fixate nitrogen? (?=.*breaks) .*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is a high energy event that breaks the chemical bond of nitrogen. Which one of these human activities does not fix nitrogen? Pumping sewage into a river Burning fossil fuels Making nitrogen fertilizers Growing legumes If humans were to disappear, how would this affect nitrogen levels in the soil? They would stop rising They would keep rising They would stop falling They would keep falling cloze Which one of these human activities does not fix nitrogen? (?=.*sewage) .*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is pumping sewage into a river. cloze If humans were to disappear, how would this affect nitrogen levels in the soil? (?=.*stop rising) .*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is they would stop rising. Humans introduce excess nitrogen into rivers by doing what? Growing crops with fertilizer Improper disposal and dumping of heavy metals Overfishing Cleaning water at water treatment plants If you wanted to fix a dead zone in the ocean by reducing the algae in the area, how might you do this? Reduce the nitrogen going into the ocean Reduce the humans in the area Increase the fish population because they feed on the algae Increase the nitrogen going into the ocean cloze Humans introduce excess nitrogen into rivers by doing what? (?=.*growing) .*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is growing crops with fertilizer. cloze If you wanted to fix a dead zone in the ocean by reducing the algae in the area, how might you do this? (?=.*reduce the nitrogen) .*$~Correct;.*$~Incorrect. The correct answer is reduce the nitrogen going into the ocean. What is nitrogen uptake? When plant roots bring fixed nitrogen, like ammonium, into the plant body The removal of fixed nitrogen, like ammonium, from a plant The return of nitrogen from the soil back to the atmosphere When nitrogen gas is taken up and absorbed from the air by leaves of certain tall trees If plants could fix and use nitrogen directly from the air, what might they not need? Bacteria Roots Water Sunlight cloze What is nitrogen uptake? (?=.*bring) .*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is when plant roots bring fixed nitrogen, like ammonium, into the plant body. cloze If plants could fix and use nitrogen directly from the air, what might they not need? (?=.*bacteria) .*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is bacteria. Legumes can form a symbiotic relationship with what? Bacteria Nitrogen Soil Bees What crop would be hurt most if it were grown in sterile soil with enough water, sun, and potassium? Peas Tomatoes Corn Pumpkins cloze Legumes can form a symbiotic relationship with what? (?=.*bacteria).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is bacteria. cloze What crop would be hurt most if it were grown in sterile soil with enough water, sun, and potassium? (?=.*peas).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is peas. What can change inorganic nitrogen to organic? A tomato plant Denitrifying bacteria Nitrifying bacteria A decaying log Generally, why can't plants use other living plants as food? Plants can't use organic nitrogen, like stems and roots, as food Plants can't use inorganic nitrogen, like stems and roots, as food Plants can't use organic nitrogen, like ammonium, as food Plants can't use inorganic nitrogen, like ammonium, as food cloze What can change inorganic nitrogen to organic? (?=.*tomato).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is a tomato plant. cloze Generally, why can't plants use other living plants as food? (?=.*organic nitrogen, like stems).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is plants can't use organic nitrogen, like stems and roots, as food. How does nitrogen mineralization return organic nitrogen to the environment? A plant or animal dies, decomposes, and its nitrogen becomes ammonium to be reused in the soil A plant absorbs nitrogen from minerals in the soil and uses it to make and release seeds Fossils of dead plants release their nitrogen back into the soil as nitrate over thousands of years Rocks and minerals absorb nitrogen from the air and leach it in the soil Where are you most likely to find nitrogen mineralization? A landfill On a rock The atmosphere Inside a plant cloze How does nitrogen mineralization return organic nitrogen to the environment? (?=.*decomposes).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is a plant or animal dies, decomposes, and its nitrogen becomes ammonium to be reused in the soil. cloze Where are you most likely to find nitrogen mineralization? (?=.*landfill).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is a landfill. What does nitrification turn ammonium into? Nitrate Nitrous oxide Nitrogen gas Oxygen Where would you expect the least nitrification to happen? An ocean dead zone A high-altitude forest On a farm The topsoil cloze What does nitrification turn ammonium into? (?=.*nitrate).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is nitrate. cloze Where would you expect the least nitrification to happen? (?=.*zone).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is an ocean dead zone. What's the most important way nitrate moves around the environment? It's carried by water It's eaten by bacteria and moves with them It's eaten by animals and moves with them It evaporates and moves through the air What could help cause a buildup of nitrate in soil? A drought Too many bees Smog Heavy rains cloze What's the most important way nitrate moves around the environment? (?=.*water).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is it's carried by water. cloze What could help cause a buildup of nitrate in soil? (?=.*drought).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is a drought. What do denitrifying bacteria turn nitrate into? Nitrogen gas Ammonium Legumes Salt If denitrification were damaging crops on a farm, what might a farmer do to stop the denitrification? Drain pools of water on and below the surface Use a nitrogen fertilizer on their crops Encourage the growth of bacteria in the soil that can change the nitrate to gas Spray pesticides on their crops cloze What do denitrifying bacteria turn nitrate into? ((?=.*gas).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is nitrogen gas. cloze If denitrification were damaging crops on a farm, what might a farmer do to stop the denitrification? (?=.*drain).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is drain pools of water on and below the surface. How might humans use denitrification? To remove nitrate from water To remove nitrate from the air To add nitrate to water To add nitrate to the air In a water treatment plant, what's most likely to mess up the removal of nitrates from water? Antibiotics put in the water Pesticides put in the water Not enough light The water treatment plant being located next to a slow flowing river cloze How might humans use denitrification? (?=.*to remove nitrate from water).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is to remove nitrate from water. cloze In a water treatment plant, what's most likely to mess up the removal of nitrates from water? (?=.*antibiotics).*$~Correct;.*~Incorrect. The correct answer is antibiotics put in the water. Age? 18-25 26-34 35-54 55-64 65 and over Gender? Male Female Other Prefer not to answer Which is the highest level of education you have completed?
